G.L. c. 218, \u00a7 19.proposition: Jurisdiction and venue are proper in this Court pursuant to G.L. c. 218, § 19 and G.L. c. 223, § 2, because the acts and omissions giving rise to this claim occurred within Essex County, and Defendant conducts business in this jurisdiction.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 2.proposition: Jurisdiction and venue are proper in this Court pursuant to G.L. c. 218, § 19 and G.L. c. 223, § 2, because the acts and omissions giving rise to this claim occurred within Essex County, and Defendant conducts business in this jurisdiction.

G.L. c. 148, \u00a7\u00a7 26E, 26F.proposition: Massachusetts law requires landlords to install, inspect, and maintain operable smoke detectors in common hallways of multi-unit residential buildings.

527 CMR 1.00 \u00a7 13.7.1.10.7.2.proposition: Massachusetts law requires landlords to install, inspect, and maintain operable smoke detectors in common hallways of multi-unit residential buildings.

Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).proposition: Defendant owed Plaintiff a duty of reasonable care to maintain the Premises, including common area smoke detection systems, in a safe and compliant condition.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).support_reasoning: The excerpt is a concurrence discussing abandonment of the invitee/licensee distinction and questioning the special treatment of trespassers. It concerns the general scope of an occupier’s duty in premises liability, not any specific duty to maintain premises or common-area smoke detection systems in a safe and compliant condition. While Mounsey broadly supports a general duty of reasonable care to lawful entrants, this particular text does not establish the specific proposition about smoke detection systems or code compliance.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).relevant_excerpt: The court holds that the measure of responsibility of an occupier should no longer depend on whether the injured person is characterized as a "licensee" rather than an "invitee," or vice versa; the question is to turn on other, more vital factors. But footnote 7 seems to say that "trespassers" stand apart, that that characterization is to remain decisive or highly influential. This tends to perpetuate, although on a smaller scale, the kind of tradition-bound and mistaken analysis that I had supposed the court was aiming to correct.

G.L. c. 148.proposition: Defendant breached this duty by: a. Failing to maintain a functional smoke detector; b. Ignoring Plaintiff’s repeated notice of the defect; and c. Violating statutory safety requirements under G.L. c. 148 and applicable fire codes.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: Defendant’s negligence further violated G.L. c. 186, § 14 (requiring landlords to maintain premises in compliance with health and safety regulations) and G.L. c. 111, § 127A (mandating compliance with sanitary and safety codes).

G.L. c. 111, \u00a7 127A.proposition: Defendant’s negligence further violated G.L. c. 186, § 14 (requiring landlords to maintain premises in compliance with health and safety regulations) and G.L. c. 111, § 127A (mandating compliance with sanitary and safety codes).

Mullins v. Pine Manor Coll., 389 Mass. 4.raw_text: Mullins v. Pine Manor Coll., 389 Mass. 47 (1983)
Mullins v. Pine Manor Coll., 389 Mass. 4.proposition: Plaintiff’s harm was the natural and probable consequence of Defendant’s omissions.
Mullins v. Pine Manor Coll., 389 Mass. 4.support_reasoning: The dissenting opinion excerpt focuses on rejecting proximate cause, repeatedly characterizing any link between the college’s omissions and the rape as speculative and not within the foreseeable risk. That directly contradicts the claimed proposition that the plaintiff’s harm was the natural and probable consequence of the defendants’ omissions. Because this is a dissent and it argues against finding proximate cause, it does not provide authority that the harm was a natural and probable consequence of the omissions.
Mullins v. Pine Manor Coll., 389 Mass. 4.relevant_excerpt: “Therefore, the plaintiff failed to show that the defendants’ negligent failure to exclude possible intruders from the plaintiff’s dormitory proximately caused her injury… Even if the rape would not have occurred but for those conditions, the jury was unwarranted in finding that those conditions proximately caused her injury… Rape was not within the foreseeable risk of failure to lock the refectory… In my opinion the plaintiff failed to introduce sufficient evidence to warrant a finding that action or inaction of the defendants was the proximate cause of her injury.”

Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141 (2006).proposition: Plaintiff’s harm was the natural and probable consequence of Defendant’s omissions.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141 (2006).support_reasoning: The proposition concerns whether the plaintiff’s harm was the natural and probable consequence of the defendant’s omissions (a causation concept). Jupin v. Kask addresses duty and foreseeability of risk for negligence, not whether the harm was the ‘natural and probable consequence’ of the defendant’s failure to act. The court expressly leaves causation and related issues for the jury and, in the strict-liability discussion, actually notes that the officer’s injuries were not the natural consequence of the alleged improper storage but were caused by an intervening third party act.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141 (2006).relevant_excerpt:
“To prevail on a negligence claim, a plaintiff must prove that the defendant owed the plaintiff a duty of reasonable care, that the defendant breached this duty, that damage resulted, and that there was a causal relation between the breach of the duty and the damage. … We generally consider the latter three questions … to be the special province of the jury.”

“The judge concluded that strict liability did not apply on these facts because Officer Jupin’s injuries were not the direct consequence of the alleged improper storage of the gun. … He added that the damage in this case was not a natural consequence of the alleged improper storage of the firearm, but was caused by an intervening act of a third party.”

Toubiana v. Priestly, 402 Mass. 84 (1988.proposition: Plaintiff’s harm was the natural and probable consequence of Defendant’s omissions.
Toubiana v. Priestly, 402 Mass. 84 (1988.support_reasoning: The opinion focuses on whether the defendant breached a duty of care and whether the plaintiff’s use of the elevator was foreseeable, not on whether the plaintiff’s harm was the natural and probable consequence of the defendant’s omissions. The court ultimately holds that the defendant was not negligent because he had no duty to guard against an obvious risk, effectively rejecting a causal or foreseeability link between his omissions and the injury. Thus, the case does not support the proposition that the plaintiff’s harm was the natural and probable consequence of the defendant’s omissions; it indicates the opposite.
Toubiana v. Priestly, 402 Mass. 84 (1988.relevant_excerpt: “Thus, the jury was unwarranted in inferring that an ordinarily prudent person in the relevant circumstances would have provided a solid elevator ceiling or a printed warning concerning the danger of extending materials from the moving elevator into the elevator shaft. It follows that the defendant’s failure to adopt either of those measures did not constitute negligence… We have concluded that those facts do not warrant a finding of the necessary foreseeability.”

Young v. Garwacki, 380 Mass. 162 (1980).proposition: Under Young v. Garwacki, 380 Mass. 162 (1980), landlords must maintain common areas in reasonable repair.
Young v. Garwacki, 380 Mass. 162 (1980).support_reasoning: The opinion expressly discusses and reaffirms that, even under the prior common law, landlords had a duty to exercise reasonable care to maintain common areas (common passageways) in safe condition, citing and relying on earlier Massachusetts cases like Lindsey and King. Young then extends landlord negligence liability beyond common areas to include demised premises, but it clearly acknowledges and is consistent with the principle that landlords must maintain common areas in reasonable repair.
Young v. Garwacki, 380 Mass. 162 (1980).relevant_excerpt: “The landlord ‘was under a separate and limited duty toward each tenant and that tenant’s visitors to exercise reasonable care to maintain the common areas in a condition not less safe than they were, or appeared to be in, at the time of the letting to the particular tenant.’ King v. G & M Realty Corp., 373 Mass. 658, 660 (1977). Lindsey v. Massios, 372 Mass. 79, 81-82 (1977). … In the landlord-tenant field, we have held that a landlord is liable to a tenant’s guest for failing to exercise due care in maintaining common passageways under the landlord’s control without regard to their condition at the time of the letting. Lindsey v. Massios, supra.”}

G.L. c. 148, \u00a7 34B.proposition: Defendant’s breach also contravened G.L. c. 148, § 34B, which imposes duties regarding fire safety equipment maintenance.

Coughlin v. Titus & Bean Graphics, Inc.,.raw_text: Coughlin v. Titus & Bean Graphics, Inc., 54 Mass. App. Ct. 633 (2002)
Coughlin v. Titus & Bean Graphics, Inc.,.proposition: Under Coughlin v. Titus & Bean Graphics, Inc., 54 Mass. App. Ct. 633 (2002), a plaintiff may recover all reasonably foreseeable damages from breach of duty.
Coughlin v. Titus & Bean Graphics, Inc.,.case_name: Coughlin v. Titus & Bean Graphics, Inc.
Coughlin v. Titus & Bean Graphics, Inc.,.support_reasoning: The opinion is about whether the defendant owed any duty at all to the victim in a negligent hiring/supervision context and concludes that, as a matter of law, no duty existed because the harm was not reasonably foreseeable. It does not discuss the scope of recoverable damages once a duty is breached, nor does it state any general rule that a plaintiff may recover all reasonably foreseeable damages from a breach of duty. The case is therefore about duty and foreseeability as a limit on duty, not about the measure of damages after breach.
Coughlin v. Titus & Bean Graphics, Inc.,.relevant_excerpt: “Under Massachusetts law, to prove a cause of action founded upon negligence, the plaintiff must satisfy the elements of duty, breach, causation, and damages. … Here, the motion judge ruled as matter of law that the defendant did not owe any such duty to the victim. … Thus, in those circumstances, Titus & Bean could not have reasonably foreseen that Kelley posed a threat to members of the public, including the victim.”

Lafond v. Frame, 327 Mass. 364 (1951).proposition: Defendant’s conduct constitutes a breach of its nondelegable duty to maintain fire safety systems in habitable premises, as recognized in Lafond v. Frame, 327 Mass. 364 (1951) and Lombardi v. Quality Fin. Servs., Inc., 915 F. Supp. 155 (D. Mass. 1996).
Lafond v. Frame, 327 Mass. 364 (1951).support_reasoning: Lafond v. Frame concerns specific performance of a real estate purchase-and-sale agreement and the seller’s duty to convey good, clear title free of encumbrances, including a mortgage and taxes. It does not involve fire safety systems, nondelegable duties regarding habitability, or landlord-tenant obligations. Citing Lafond as authority for a nondelegable duty to maintain fire safety systems in habitable premises mischaracterizes the scope and subject matter of the decision.
Lafond v. Frame, 327 Mass. 364 (1951).relevant_excerpt: “The plaintiff’s case depended upon proof that the defendant was able to give good and clear title, or that her inability to do so was the result of her own fault or collusion. … The clause is no protection to an owner who is not acting in good faith and does not intend to carry out the agreement.”

Lombardi v. Quality Fin. Servs., Inc., 9.raw_text: Lombardi v. Quality Fin. Servs., Inc., 915 F. Supp. 155 (D. Mass. 1996)
Lombardi v. Quality Fin. Servs., Inc., 9.proposition: Defendant’s conduct constitutes a breach of its nondelegable duty to maintain fire safety systems in habitable premises, as recognized in Lafond v. Frame, 327 Mass. 364 (1951) and Lombardi v. Quality Fin. Servs., Inc., 915 F. Supp. 155 (D. Mass. 1996).
Lombardi v. Quality Fin. Servs., Inc., 9.support_reasoning: This opinion concerns federal removal jurisdiction from tribal courts under 28 U.S.C. § 1441 and related statutes. It does not address premises liability, nondelegable duties, fire safety systems, or habitability, nor does it cite or discuss Lafond v. Frame or any similar principle. Accordingly, it cannot be relied upon as authority for a nondelegable duty to maintain fire safety systems in habitable premises.
Lombardi v. Quality Fin. Servs., Inc., 9.relevant_excerpt: Section 1441 of Title 28 only authorizes the removal of actions “brought in a State court.” 28 U.S.C. § 1441(a). The question is whether to interpret this language strictly, so that it encompasses only state courts, or whether to apply it, by analogy, to all non-federal trial courts. When the terms of a statute are plain, those terms are conclusive and must be followed… There is no ambiguity in the text of 28 U.S.C. § 1441: it refers specifically to state courts, and to state courts only.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: For costs and reasonable interest pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 6B;

Mass. R. Civ. P. 38.proposition: Pursuant to Mass. R. Civ. P. 38, Plaintiff demands trial by jury on all issues so triable.
